questions.answerC: Drivers should leave 100 yards of distance between their vehicle and the next.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the safest response to a hazard on the road. You can almost always turn to avoid an obstacle faster than you can stop.

questions.question: Looking far ahead of your vehicle while driving is:
questions.answerA: Discouraged, as there is little you can do about something far up the road.
questions.answerB: Encouraged to help you identify hazards as early as possible.
questions.answerD: Only encouraged if you are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Good drivers look down the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. This makes it possible to identify hazards early, when drivers are more likely to have time to respond appropriately.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should move your vehicle quickly.
questions.answerB: You should move your vehicle slowly.
questions.answerC: The move should be made with a jerking motion.
questions.answerD: You do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly to maintain control of your vehicle. Doing this will also allow a driver that you did not see time to move out of the way of your vehicle. Use the proper turn signal to communicate with other road users.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, the coolant temperature gauge should:
questions.answerA: Not change from its original position.
questions.answerB: Gradually rise to the normal operating range.
questions.answerC: Jump quickly to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: Flash until it reaches the normal operating range.
questions.explanation: Keep an eye on the gauges after starting the engine. The coolant temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indicator of when to upshift?
questions.answerB: RPMs
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: If stopped on the road or shoulder, within 10 minutes, you must:
questions.answerB: Alert local law enforcement.
questions.answerC: Stand behind your vehicle and motion for traffic to pass you.
questions.answerD: Call a mechanic.
questions.explanation: If stopped on the side of the road, you must place emergency warning devices, such as reflective warning triangles, within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: How can a person check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times and hold the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake makes a squeak, there may be a problem.
questions.answerD: Remove the rear wheel and listen for a noise when the brake pedal is depressed.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see, such as at dawn or dusk, what is the best way to make your vehicle more visible?
questions.answerB: Use your low beam lights.
questions.answerD: Do not use any lights.
questions.explanation: In conditions of poor visibility (such as at dawn, at dusk, in rain, or in snow), you should turn on your low beam headlights to make your vehicle easier to see. Do not use your high beams when driving near other vehicles.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts could be loose.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: What is a tire load?
questions.answerA: The minimum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerB: The maximum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.explanation: Tire load is defined as the maximum safe weight that a tire can carry at a specified pressure.

questions.question: If a vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. In what condition should the belt be?
questions.answerB: Tight
questions.answerD: Bumpy
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with air brakes that has a belt-driven air compressor, you should check the condition and tightness of the belt. It should be in good condition.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Increases your braking distance.
questions.answerC: Creates a loud squeaking noise when being used.
questions.answerD: Helps to ensure control while braking.
questions.explanation: ABS increases a driver's control during braking. It will not necessarily change the distance needed for a vehicle to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: Livestock:
questions.answerA: Should never be transported on a trailer.
questions.answerB: Must be inspected by a law enforcement officer.
questions.answerC: Can cause unsafe handling when being transported on a trailer due to their movement.
questions.answerD: Can only be transported by a person registered as a farmer.
questions.explanation: Livestock being transported as cargo can move around and shift their weight in transit, which can result in unsafe handling.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: The safety belt should:
questions.answerB: Latch securely.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should verify that the safety belt is securely mounted, adjusts, latches properly, and is not ripped or frayed.

questions.question: When approaching a construction worker who is near the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.explanation: Always drive with caution through work zones. You should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the roadway.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to stay awake on long trips.
questions.answerB: Is distracting.
questions.answerD: Should be used to prevent rust from forming.
questions.explanation: Always accelerate smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Before starting down a hill, be sure to:
questions.answerB: Switch into a high gear.
questions.answerD: Switch into a low gear.
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: Most CDL holders have ____ licenses.
questions.answerB: Exempted
questions.answerD: Non-exempted
questions.explanation: Most CDL holders who drive CMVs in interstate commerce are non-excepted interstate commerce drivers.

questions.question: An underloaded front axle:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged as front axles are usually less strong than other axles.
questions.answerC: Is discouraged as it can cause steering problems.
questions.answerD: Is discouraged as it can improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: Underloading a front axle may make it impossible to safely steer your vehicle. Keep weight distribution in mind when loading cargo.

questions.question: Properly adjusted mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.answerB: 100 feet
questions.answerD: 1,000 feet
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: During the steering box portion of the vehicle inspection test, you should not:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the steering box is securely mounted.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the steering box is free of leaks.
questions.answerC: Look for missing bolts in the steering box.
questions.answerD: Assume all cotter keys are present.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that the steering box is securely mounted. Check for missing nuts, bolts, and cotter keys. Be sure that there are no power steering fluid leaks and that there is no damage to power steering hoses.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that the landing gear is:
questions.answerB: Fully raised.
questions.answerC: More worn on the passenger's side than on the driver's side.
questions.answerD: Well lit.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer during a vehicle inspection test, ensure that its landing gear has no missing parts and that it is fully raised. The crank handle should be secure and the support frame should not be damaged.

questions.question: When operating a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerB: Before beginning to drive.
questions.explanation: It is critical to the safe operation of a school bus that mirrors be properly adjusted. Always check each mirror before operating the bus.

questions.question: If a gate controlling a railroad crossing does not go back up after a train passes, you should:
questions.answerB: Wait for another vehicle to cross the tracks first to see if it is safe.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing and a gate fails to return to its open position after a train passes, call your dispatcher. Do not attempt to drive around the lowered gate.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror in a school bus is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: When students unload, they should:
questions.answerA: Remain seated until they are told to exit.
questions.answerB: Stand up and head toward the door while the bus is still moving.
questions.answerC: Exit the bus and stand next to the bus until it leaves.
questions.answerD: Jump down from the top step.
questions.explanation: Students leaving a school bus should remain seated until they are cleared to exit. After exiting, they should walk at least 10 feet away from the bus to a location where the driver can see them.

questions.question: If a student drops an item while approaching the bus, the student should:
questions.answerA: Stop and pick up the object.
questions.answerB: Have another student pick up the object.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Just leave the item alone and walk away.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: Must maintain four points of contact with the vehicle.
questions.answerB: May turn to face the road before your exit is complete.
questions.answerC: Must be facing away from the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Must be facing the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If a student drops an item near a stopped bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Hurry and pick up the item.
questions.answerB: Leave the item behind.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Have another student pick it up.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: An inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: Inspect the outside of the bus.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus. It should be adjusted to show every student on the bus, including the students directly behind the driver.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and there is no nearby shelter, where should students go?
questions.answerB: To the closest tree
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough away from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: If asked to sight-side back your vehicle into an alley, you should first:
questions.answerA: Pull directly into the alley parking space.
questions.answerB: Turn your vehicle to the right to position yourself directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Pull past the alley and stop perpendicular to the outer boundary.
questions.answerD: Pull past the alley and stop parallel to the outer boundary.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerB: Change gears.
questions.answerD: Stay in your lane.
questions.explanation: When crossing railroad tracks during the on-road driving skills test, you must not stop, switch gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in the crossing.

questions.question: ABS helps you:
questions.answerB: Keep the wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Count the number of students boarding the bus.
questions.answerD: Predict the weather.
questions.explanation: An Ant-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps stop a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard brake applications.

questions.question: The overhead rearview mirror is located:
questions.answerA: On the outside left of the bus.
questions.answerB: On the outside right of the bus.
questions.answerC: Above the windshield inside the bus.
questions.explanation: In a school bus, the overhead rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side.

questions.question: When loading or unloading passengers, a bus may need to be:
questions.answerB: Placed in fourth gear.
questions.answerD: Placed in first gear.
questions.explanation: When stopped to load or unload students at a stop, the transmission of a school bus should be placed in park. If there is not a park setting, the bus should be put in neutral.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: If a parent asks you to change the location of a bus stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Agree and pick up students at the new bus stop.
questions.answerB: Continue to pick up students at the original bus stop.
questions.answerC: Change the bus stop if the new location fits into your route.
questions.answerD: Use both locations as bus stops.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver does not have the authority to change the location of a school bus stop. Only appropriate school district officials can determine the locations of bus stops.

questions.question: When taking the driving test and asked to make a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use a turn signal since you were told to make the turn.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only to your right.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: What should be used to check for proper tire inflation?
questions.answerB: A tire iron
questions.answerD: A lug nut
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must use a tire gauge to check for proper tire inflation. You will not receive passing credit if you simply kick the tires.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time, emphasizing different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time so you are less likely to forget something.
questions.answerD: By someone other than the driver.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: Before leaving a bus stop, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make sure no students are running to catch the bus.
questions.answerB: Make sure students have placed their backpacks in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Make sure students have opened the emergency vent.
questions.answerD: Make sure students are facing the rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: Before pulling away from a bus stop, a driver should make sure that there are no students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerB: Should be supervised by someone other than the driver.
questions.explanation: Passengers may stumble when getting on or off of a school bus. The driver should caution passengers to watch their step when exiting.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: What should properly adjusted outside side flat mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see?
questions.answerA: The sides of the school bus
questions.answerB: Under the school bus
questions.answerC: The front tires touching the ground
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, the outside side flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see along the sides of the bus; the rear tires touching the ground; and 200 feet behind the bus.

questions.question: After driving over a bridge during the driving skills test, you may be asked to recall.
questions.answerB: The color of a sign you just passed.
questions.answerC: How many lanes of traffic there were on the bridge.
questions.answerD: If there was a crosswalk on the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you drive over a bridge during the on-road driving skills test, the examiner may ask you afterwards to recall the bridge's posted weight limit.

questions.question: Once stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the four-way flashers because it is just a test, not an emergency.
questions.answerC: Leave the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Park in front of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: Once you have stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver during the on-road driving skills test, you must activate your four-way flashers and shift into neutral or park. You must not block any driveways, intersections, fire hydrants, or signs.

questions.question: When asked to complete a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: During the pre-trip inspection test, you will be:
questions.answerA: Expected to explain your knowledge of the pre-trip process.
questions.answerB: Watching someone else check your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Watching a film on how to inspect a vehicle.
questions.answerD: Changing all the tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the change as soon as the examiner asks, without looking.
questions.answerB: Use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: Make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to change lanes during the on-road driving test. When the examiner asks you to do this, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use the proper signals before changing lanes.

questions.question: If a gate controlling a railroad crossing does not go back up after a train passes, you should:
questions.answerB: Wait for another vehicle to cross the tracks first to see if it is safe.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing and a gate fails to return to its open position after a train passes, call your dispatcher. Do not attempt to drive around the lowered gate.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on specific driving maneuvers, as well as your general driving behavior.

questions.question: As a general rule, student safety is best maintained by:
questions.answerB: Letting some students evacuate the bus.
questions.answerC: Letting students evacuate the bus and scatter.
questions.explanation: In most emergency or crisis situations, students will be safest and easiest to keep under control if they remain on the school bus. Generally, students should be kept on the bus as long as it does not expose them to unnecessary risks or injury.

questions.question: A school bus must be evacuated if:
questions.answerA: The bus has stalled in winter weather conditions.
questions.answerB: The air conditioning system has broken.
questions.answerC: There is any imminent danger of collision.
questions.answerD: Students are getting motion sickness.
questions.explanation: During emergency situations, it is usually safest for students to remain on a school bus. Evacuations are mandatory if the bus has stalled on railroad tracks, if the bus is on fire or there is a threat of fire, or if there is a hazardous materials spill. Students should be evacuated any time there is imminent danger of collision.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: If you must drive during periods of high winds, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: A school bus's long sides are vulnerable to being pushed by winds. If you must drive in windy conditions, you should maintain a strong grip on the steering wheel, try to anticipate wind gusts, and slow down. If necessary, contact your dispatcher for instructions on how to proceed.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Hop directly from their seat to the ground.
questions.answerB: Maintain at least one point of contact with their vehicle.
questions.answerC: Be turned to face their vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerB: On the material's packaging.
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.answerB: Hooks.
questions.explanation: Always protect containers of hazardous materials. When loading hazardous materials, never use equipment that could damage containers or packaging, such as hooks.

questions.question: Shippers package in order to ____ hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Release
questions.explanation: Shippers package hazardous materials in a way that is meant to completely contain the materials. Vehicles should be placarded to communicate the risk of the cargo.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You can proceed without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.answerD: You can proceed without stopping if no other vehicles are within sight.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track.

questions.question: A driver must take the HazMat knowledge test:
questions.answerB: Prior to every CDL renewal.
questions.answerD: Only once.
questions.explanation: You must take and pass the written English version of the HazMat knowledge test and be cleared through a federal background check before every renewal of your CDL.

questions.question: In the event of a fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerB: Throw water on the doors.
questions.answerC: Find someone else to open the doors.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. In this case, leave the doors closed because opening the doors could worsen the fire by supplying it with more oxygen.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should be used only by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.explanation: When required, hazardous materials placards must be placed on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerB: A return address.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.answerD: The word "fragile."
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of a hazardous material?
questions.answerB: A contractor
questions.answerD: Everyone
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for using the hazardous materials regulations to determine the product's identification number, proper shipping name, hazard class, and packing group. They are also responsible for determining the correct packaging, labels, markings, and placards to use.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in the business of firework or munition dealing.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that involves such materials. Examples include paint dealers; chemical suppliers; scientific supply houses; pest control businesses; agricultural supply firms; and dealers in explosives, munitions, or fireworks.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: Who is responsible for installing placards on a vehicle?
questions.answerB: The carrier
questions.answerD: The mechanic
questions.explanation: While shippers of hazardous materials are responsible for providing necessary placards, it is the driver's responsibility to actually place them on the vehicle.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerB: Closed
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerD: Made of wood.
questions.explanation: Brace containers so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation. All hazardous materials packages must be secured.

questions.question: Unless it is clearly unsafe, what does a driver need to accept a package?
questions.answerB: A notarized statement
questions.answerD: A contract
questions.explanation: When the shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerB: A return address.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages that contain liquid containers must have orientation markers. Arrows displayed on the box should be pointing in the correct upright direction.

questions.question: If cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.answerD: Spray the leaking containers with water.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: If you're transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you should notify other drivers:
questions.answerB: With reflective triangles.
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down while you are transporting explosives and you need to use warning signals, use reflective triangles or red electric lights. Never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses, when transporting explosives.

questions.question: Hazardous materials may be transported:
questions.answerA: By any driver with a CDL.
questions.answerB: By a driver with a CDL and hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: In rural areas by any driver.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerB: Eyeballing the tires.
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.answerD: Weighing the tires.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is by:
questions.answerB: Attending hazardous materials training courses.
questions.answerD: Reading labels.
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in a trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerB: Cleaned with water.
questions.answerC: Left to air dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to corrosive liquids must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should not cross a railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching a railroad crossing, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, you must stop before crossing railroad tracks. This is true whether the tanks are full or empty.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerB: Greased.
questions.answerD: Removed.
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: If you identify hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving to find a phone booth and call the National Response Center.
questions.answerB: Park the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.explanation: If you discover that a cargo of hazardous materials is leaking from your vehicle, you should park the vehicle as soon as possible. The longer you continue driving, the longer the trail of contamination becomes. While this creates potential danger and harm to others, it also increases clean-up expenses.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, a driver needs:
questions.answerB: A CDL with hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement.
questions.explanation: To drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, you must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: What does a hazardous materials shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.answerD: The cost of the materials
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes the hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: If a product requires a "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard, the placard must be used when transporting:
questions.answerA: More than 50 pounds of the product.
questions.answerB: More than 10 pounds of the product.
questions.answerD: The product in a non-sealed container.
questions.explanation: For applicable materials, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard and the appropriate hazard class placard must always be displayed, even for small amounts of the materials.

questions.question: On a shipping paper describing both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may be identified by being:
questions.answerB: Written in pencil.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous items must be clearly identified on the paper. They may be entered first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description.

questions.question: What must be included in emergency response information?
questions.answerB: Where the materials originated
questions.answerD: Cost of the material
questions.explanation: Emergency response information for a shipment of hazardous materials must include details about any immediate hazards to health that are associated with the materials.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerB: Refuse it.
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: Unless a package is clearly unsafe, what does the driver need to accept a package of hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: A notarized statement
questions.answerD: A court order
questions.explanation: Unless a package is clearly unsafe or does not comply with the Hazardous Materials Regulations, you may accept the shipper's certification that it was properly packaged.

questions.question: An explosive material is most likely categorized as a ____ hazard.
questions.answerB: Class 3
questions.answerD: Class 7
questions.explanation: Class 1 hazardous materials are typically items that present certain explosion or fire hazards.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may be:
questions.answerA: Kept in a pouch attached to the driver's side door.
questions.answerB: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.answerB: An air conditioner.
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: During a cargo fire, opening the trailer doors may actually cause the fire to expand because doing so:
questions.answerB: Changes the temperature of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Provides more moisture to the trailer.
questions.explanation: When experiencing a cargo fire, it may be a bad idea to open the doors to the trailer. Doing so allows oxygen to enter the area, potentially causing the fire to flare up and expand.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.answerB: Flammable.
questions.answerD: Corrosive.
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the markings and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: It is always a good idea to compare package markings and labels to accompanying shipping papers. Always make sure the shipper has displayed the correct basic description on the shipping paper and has provided the proper labels on the packages.

questions.question: Shippers must keep a copy of shipping papers for:
questions.answerB: Six months.
questions.answerD: Two years.
questions.explanation: Shippers must retain a physical copy or an electronic image of hazardous materials shipping papers for a minimum of two years after the materials are accepted by the initial carrier. For hazardous waste, this increases to three years.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, what is an effective way to learn about transporting hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: Attending hazardous materials training courses
questions.answerD: Working on cars
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.answerB: Where materials originate.
questions.answerD: Materials' manufacturers.
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: What is the symbol for a marine pollutant?
questions.answerA: The image of a waves in a yellow triangle with an X through through the waves
questions.answerB: The image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish
questions.answerC: A light blue square with a dark blue X through the square
questions.answerD: The image of a bird in a red octagon
questions.explanation: The marine pollutant marking is the image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish.

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.answerB: The shipper
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to warn drivers and others about the risks of the materials by putting hazard warning labels on packages, putting placards on the transporting vehicles, and providing proper shipping papers and emergency response information.

questions.question: You may leave a vehicle that is carrying explosives unattended:
questions.answerB: In a safe haven.
questions.answerC: On the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: In the event of a cargo fire, opening trailer doors may cause a fire to expand because:
questions.answerA: Oxygen will be allowed into the area.
questions.answerB: The temperature of the trailer will change.
questions.answerD: It will provide more light.
questions.explanation: In the event of a cargo fire, you should not open the trailer doors. Doing this could cause the fire to flare up by giving it access to more oxygen.

questions.question: What does a hazardous materials shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.answerD: The cost of the materials
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes the hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify:
questions.answerA: That the package does not contain hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: That the package has been prepared in compliance with the rules.
questions.answerC: That the package was packed at a different location.
questions.explanation: A shipper of hazardous materials must certify on the shipping paper that the shipment has been prepared in accordance with the rules.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerB: Value of the materials.
questions.answerD: Origination of the materials.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: If you identify hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving to find a phone booth and call the National Response Center.
questions.answerB: Park the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.explanation: If you discover that a cargo of hazardous materials is leaking from your vehicle, you should park the vehicle as soon as possible. The longer you continue driving, the longer the trail of contamination becomes. While this creates potential danger and harm to others, it also increases clean-up expenses.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: Can only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerD: Can be driven if it does not contain radioactive materials.
questions.explanation: A vehicle carrying hazardous materials must be appropriately placarded to be driven. An improperly placarded vehicle may only be driven if necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the transporting vehicle.

questions.question: If a substance is transported in a reportable quantity, which letters must appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.answerB: LT
questions.answerD: NT
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials are being transported in a reportable quantity in one package, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class should:
questions.answerA: Be abbreviated if using a small piece of paper.
questions.answerB: Only be abbreviated if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: On hazardous materials shipping papers, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class must not be abbreviated, unless specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Placed in the glove box.
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.answerD: Laminated.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerB: Eyeballing the tires.
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.answerD: Weighing the tires.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared by both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.answerD: Brakes on only one side of the vehicle will work.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system consists of two separate air brake systems, connected by a single set of brake controls. Each system has its own air tanks.

questions.question: Wheel rims that have been welded should:
questions.answerA: Be placed in the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Be placed in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Not be used.
questions.explanation: Wheels and rims with welding repairs are not safe to be used. Replace any damaged wheels and rims.

questions.question: When entering traffic, a large vehicle usually needs:
questions.answerA: Less space than is needed for a car.
questions.answerB: About the same amount of space as is needed for a car.
questions.answerC: More space than is needed for a car.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle requires more space when entering or crossing traffic than a smaller vehicle. This is not only because the vehicle itself is larger, but also because it needs a longer distance to accelerate.

questions.question: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunctions:
questions.answerB: A yellow lamp will light up on the control panel.
questions.answerD: The brakes will not work.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with ABS, a yellow malfunction lamp on the instrument panel will illuminate to alert you if the braking system is not working.

questions.question: To prevent a set of doubles or triples from rolling over, you should:
questions.answerB: Steer aggressively.
questions.explanation: To avoid rolling over, you should drive slowly and steer gently when turning, taking curves, and driving around corners. Remember that a safe speed for a straight truck or single trailer combination may be too fast for a double or triple trailer combination.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be:
questions.answerA: Slightly higher than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Level with the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Next to the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: On any upgrade, gravity will:
questions.answerB: Slow down your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not impact the speed of your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Cause your vehicle to swerve to the left.
questions.explanation: When driving uphill, you are fighting the force of gravity, which will slow down your vehicle.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle, you should not:
questions.answerA: Park in an area away from buildings, trees, brush, and other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Pull into a service station.
questions.answerC: Notify emergency services of your problem and your location.
questions.explanation: In the event of a vehicle fire, you should leave the road and stop in an open area. Do not pull into a service station as fuels at the service station could catch fire. Report the fire and your location to emergency services.

questions.question: If an unusual noise or feeling occurs in a vehicle while it is being driven, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle does alright until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the situation to determine the proper solution.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything while driving that does not feel right, you should have it checked out.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.answerB: 100 psi.
questions.answerD: 80 psi.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: Brakes out of adjustment will:
questions.answerB: Cause some of the brakes to overwork and malfunction.
questions.explanation: Brakes out of adjustment will fade before those that are properly adjusted. Brake adjustment must be checked frequently to help prevent brake issues.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Prevents wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to turn a large vehicle.
questions.answerD: Assists with the operation of brake lights.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard braking.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.answerB: C-cam drum brake.
questions.answerD: P-cam disc brake.
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but do not need to be repaired immediately.
questions.answerD: Are extremely dangerous.
questions.explanation: The suspension system is responsible for supporting a vehicle, supporting its load, and keeping its axles in place. When inspecting your vehicle, check for damaged or missing spring hangers, spring leaves, shock absorbers, u-bolts, and frame members. Broken parts in the suspension system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located inside:
questions.answerB: A brake drum.
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: Eating while driving is:
questions.answerA: A good way to save time.
questions.answerB: A dangerous activity.
questions.answerC: Acceptable if you are eating foods that are easy to eat.
questions.explanation: Smoking, eating, or drinking are distracting activities and should be avoided while you are driving. Instead, plan ahead and allow yourself time to stop to eat when making a lengthy trip.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.answerB: The brakes may stop working.
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out of the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it. Air brakes may cease to work effectively if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: How long should it take for oil pressure to reach a normal level when starting a vehicle?
questions.answerB: About a minute
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see other vehicles, such as at dawn or dusk, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn your lights on.
questions.explanation: When driving at dawn, at dusk, or in inclement weather, you should use your headlights on their low beam setting to increase your visibility.

questions.question: If a tire fails, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Keep one hand on the steering wheel and use their other hand to wave to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Stomp on the brakes.
questions.answerD: Accelerate.
questions.explanation: If a tire fails, braking could cause a loss of control. Unless braking is necessary to avoid a hazard, you should stay off the brakes until your vehicle has slowed considerably. Only then should you brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop.

questions.question: The emergency air line supplies air to the:
questions.answerB: Trailer air tanks.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks, and the second is to control the emergency brakes on combination vehicles.

questions.question: Why should the steps of a pre-trip inspection be done in the same order each time?
questions.answerA: Because you will be less likely to forget to check something
questions.answerB: Because it will be faster
questions.answerC: Because it is required by law
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly before other vehicles get into the lane you wish to occupy.
questions.answerB: Move slowly, in case another vehicle is in the lane you wish to occupy.
questions.answerD: Never use the right lane.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If you did not see drivers who are already using the lane you wish to occupy, this will give them a chance to get out of your way or honk their horns to alert you. Always signal before changing lanes.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it may cause the wheels to lock.
questions.explanation: You should not brake while making a quick turn to avoid a hazard. Doing so could cause your wheels to lock and make your vehicle skid out of control.

questions.question: A combination vehicle has ____ air line(s).
questions.answerB: Two
questions.explanation: Every combination vehicle has two air lines: the service line and the emergency line.

questions.question: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in the cab and call for help.
questions.answerB: Exit the cab and walk away from the tracks.
questions.answerC: Motion for another driver to push your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks for any reason, you should immediately exit the vehicle and walk away from the tracks. Contact the proper emergency authorities.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: A driver should test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When starting an engine as part of a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Place the engine in first gear.
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: Where must placards be placed?
questions.answerA: Only on the front of a vehicle
questions.answerB: On the front, back and both sides of a vehicle
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of a vehicle
questions.answerD: Only on the passenger's side of the vehicle
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials that require placarding, there must be identical placards placed on the front, rear, and both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: An open automobile window in cold weather may indicate that the driver is:
questions.answerB: Inappropriately dressed.
questions.answerC: Using the heat inside their vehicle.
questions.answerD: Enjoying the fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' behaviors and identify clues that indicate when person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. A person driving with their window open in cold weather may be impaired.

questions.question: When driving, your mirrors should:
questions.answerA: Not be used, as they are distracting.
questions.answerB: Not be used unless there is traffic.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driver who might be a hazard?
questions.answerA: A driver operating a vehicle without first scraping ice off the windshield
questions.answerB: The operator of a rental truck
questions.answerC: The driver of a station wagon with items covering the back windows
questions.answerD: A person operating a pick-up truck
questions.explanation: Drivers with blocked vision may pose hazards to others on the road. Examples of such drivers include those who haven't scraped ice off of their windshields; those driving vehicles loaded with large items blocking the windows; and those who are driving rental trucks without being used to the limited rear visibility of a truck.

questions.question: Look for matching colors when coupling glad hands. Service lines are often:
questions.answerB: Orange.
questions.answerD: Blue.
questions.explanation: When coupling glad hands, make sure to couple together matching glad hands. To help drivers avoid mistakes, color coding is sometimes used. Service lines are often coded with the color blue and emergency lines are often coded with the color red.

questions.question: Escape ramps are ramps that can be used:
questions.answerB: To leave the highway and enter a two-lane highway.
questions.answerC: To stop runaway vehicles on steep downhills.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are constructed in areas with steep downgrades to allow a means of safely stopping runaway vehicles. They consist of a long bed of loose, soft material, and sometimes an uphill slope.

questions.question: Place the trailer air supply control in its "emergency" position to test:
questions.answerB: A coupling device.
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: To control surge when stopping, you should not:
questions.answerA: Keep a steady pressure on the brakes.
questions.answerB: Brake well in advance of a stop.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a surge in a tank vehicle, slow or stop while keeping a steady pressure on the brakes and do not release the brakes too early. Brake well in advance of a stop and increase your following distance.

questions.question: When encountering fog, you will be safest if you:
questions.answerB: Don’t drive in the fog.
questions.answerD: Follow the vehicle ahead of you closely.
questions.explanation: Fog can quickly deteriorate drivers' ability to see the road, other drivers, and other hazards. Avoid driving in fog if at all possible.

questions.question: When making a turn, when should you cancel your turn signal?
questions.answerB: In the middle of the turn
questions.answerD: It does not matter.
questions.explanation: When turning or changing lanes, you should signal early and signal continuously. Cancel your turn signal once the turn or lane change is complete.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Get upset.
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: Should never be done the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be done in the same order.
questions.answerC: Do not need to be done if the driver is familiar with the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection should be completed in the same order every time. This will make it easier for you to learn all of the steps and will make it less likely that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.answerB: Triangles.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: While driving:
questions.answerA: A driver does not need to inform others of their intentions.
questions.answerB: A driver should only use turn signals if a vehicle is next to them.
questions.answerC: A driver should not use a turn signal if their lane change will be obvious.
questions.answerD: A driver should always use turn signals to inform others of their intentions.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a driver always uses proper signals to make their intentions known to others on the road.

questions.question: When driving a tractor-trailer equipped with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would otherwise.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Brake using less pressure than you would otherwise use.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: If you must make a quick stop while transporting liquids, one safe option is to:
questions.answerB: Apply the emergency brake.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.answerD: Use the stab braking method.
questions.explanation: If you must make a quick stop to avoid an accident while transporting liquid cargo, it may be a good idea to use the stab braking method. Remember that attempting to steer quickly while braking may cause your vehicle to tip over, especially if it has a high center of gravity.

questions.question: When drivers turn, they usually:
questions.answerA: Look in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Look in the direction opposite the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, drivers usually look in the direction of their turn. If a driver fails to signal before a turn or lane change, their body movements may still provide a clue that they are planning to turn.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Can cause mechanical damage.
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of a hazardous material?
questions.answerB: A contractor
questions.answerD: Everyone
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for using the hazardous materials regulations to determine the product's identification number, proper shipping name, hazard class, and packing group. They are also responsible for determining the correct packaging, labels, markings, and placards to use.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.answerD: Air pressure is above 45 psi.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: The heavier the vehicle:
questions.answerA: The less important the brakes become.
questions.answerB: The harder the brakes need to work.
questions.answerC: The quieter the brakes will sound.
questions.explanation: The heavier a vehicle is, the more the brakes will need to work to bring the vehicle to a complete stop.

questions.question: A lightly-loaded combination vehicle will stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have high traction.
questions.answerB: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have low traction.
questions.answerC: The brakes only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.answerD: The suspension springs only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction on a light trailer than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: When a tank that is divided by bulkheads is being loaded with liquid cargo, most of the weight should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the top of the tank.
questions.answerB: In the middle of the tank.
questions.answerC: In the rear of the tank.
questions.explanation: When filling a tank that is divided by bulkheads, make sure that you do not place too much weight on the front or rear of the vehicle.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: If there is open space in the truck.
questions.answerC: If the amount of hazardous materials in the truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.answerD: If the hazardous materials create an inhalation hazard.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. They identify the specific class or classes of materials being carried and warn others of relevant hazards.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: If cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.answerD: Spray the leaking containers with water.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: While driving:
questions.answerA: Creating a text is not permitted, but reading a text is.
questions.answerB: Creating a text is permitted, but reading a text is not.
questions.answerC: Neither creating nor reading a text is permitted.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving a CMV is prohibited. "Texting" is defined as manually entering text into, or reading text from, an electronic device.

questions.question: When completing pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: The inspections should be done the same way each time.
questions.answerB: Different items should be checked each time.
questions.answerC: It is acceptable to check items in a different order each time.
questions.answerD: Not every item needs to be inspected each time.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.
