questions.question: If your engine runs a pump used during delivery of compressed gas, you should turn off the engine:
questions.answerB: After unhooking the hoses.
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: ____ are the most likely to be affected by strong winds.
questions.answerB: Heavy vehicles
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult for a driver to maintain control of their vehicle. Usually, this is especially true for drivers of lighter CMVs.

questions.question: When driving, keeping space between your vehicle and other vehicles is:
questions.answerB: Important.
questions.answerD: Optional.
questions.explanation: For the safety of everyone on the road, it is essential that you maintain adequate cushions of space between your vehicle and other vehicles. This will help ensure that if you need to stop your vehicle, you will be able to do so without hitting someone else.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the driver’s side of a trailer.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is top-heavy, it is more likely to roll over. The weight of cargo should be positioned as low in a trailer as possible to minimize this risk.

questions.question: To distinguish between hazardous and non-hazardous materials on a shipping paper:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials should be listed at the bottom of the paper.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials should be listed at the top of the paper.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials should be highlighted in the same color as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.answerD: The non-hazardous materials should be marked with an "X."
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be differentiated in one of three ways. They must be listed first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description in a column labeled "HM."

questions.question: During an inspection, it is most important to check your tank vehicle for:
questions.answerB: Rust.
questions.answerD: Tires.
questions.explanation: When inspecting any style of tank, the most important thing for a driver to check for is leaks. Transporting any type of gas or liquid in a leaking tank is illegal.

questions.question: When loading liquid cargo, you should take the ____ into account.
questions.answerB: Quality of the roads
questions.explanation: Factors that affect how much liquid is safe to load into your tank include how much the liquid will expand in transit, the weight of the liquid, and legal weight limits.

questions.question: If color-coded, which color is used to identify service lines?
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.explanation: Air lines are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes when coupling glad hands. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Rims with a missing lug nut are acceptable if there are at least four other lug nuts on the rim.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring is acceptable if the vehicle is being driven at speeds under 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.answerD: Welded repairs are acceptable for wheels on rear axles.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs can be a dangerous defect. Mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings are not safe to be used. Wheels or rims with welded repairs are not safe.

questions.question: A commercial motor vehicle should:
questions.answerA: Not be equipped with a fire extinguisher, unless transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not be equipped with a fire extinguisher, unless the vehicle will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerC: Never be equipped with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerD: Always be equipped with at least one fire extinguisher.
questions.explanation: Vehicles must be equipped with the appropriate emergency equipment. When inspecting a CMV, you should check for at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses, unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers; and the appropriate warning devices to be used when the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: If you are backing and become unsure about your path of travel, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop and get out to look.
questions.answerC: Continue backing, but more slowly than before.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure of your path while you are driving in reverse, you should stop, exit the vehicle, and recheck your path of travel.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance of driving to:
questions.answerA: Recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: Once you have begun to drive after a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: Older trailers are not equipped with spring brakes. This means that if the air supply for a vehicle's air braking system leaks away:
questions.answerB: The trailer will not have brakes.
questions.explanation: Older trailers do not have spring brakes. This means that if the air supply in an older trailer's air tank has leaked away, there will be no working brakes connected to the trailer and its wheels will turn freely.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.answerB: When partially loaded.
questions.answerD: When mostly loaded.
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: If you must back up, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible to complete the maneuver quickly.
questions.answerB: First walk the line of travel to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, you should exit the cab and check your path for obstacles before beginning the maneuver. Drive as slowly as you can, checking your mirrors on both sides.

questions.question: Slippery roadways usually:
questions.answerA: Make it more difficult to stop a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Make it easier to stop a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Make it easier to drive a vehicle.
questions.answerD: Can be avoided by driving at night.
questions.explanation: It takes a longer distance to stop a vehicle on a slippery road than it does on a dry road. Use caution when driving under conditions that could cause a road surface to become slippery.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerB: Throw water on the doors.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn’t see you.
questions.answerD: Wave to other drivers.
questions.explanation: It is always safest to assume that other drivers, bicyclists, and pedestrians don't see you. Be prepared for the possibility that they may suddenly move into your path. It may be safe to lightly tap your horn or flash your lights as you pass.

questions.question: When driving a tank, a surge:
questions.answerB: Can be dangerous.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern for drivers.
questions.answerD: Does not usually happen with liquids.
questions.explanation: Partially-filled tanks of liquid cargo can be vulnerable to surge. Liquid surge is an occurrence in which a wave of liquid sloshes from one end or side of a tank to the other, causing dangerous effects on handling.

questions.question: Escape ramps are:
questions.answerA: Ramps to exit the interstate quickly.
questions.answerB: Ramps connecting four-lane highways and two-lane highways.
questions.answerC: Ramps that can be used by stop runaway vehicles on steep downhills.
questions.answerD: Ramps that cannot be used by automobiles.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are constructed in areas with steep downgrades to allow a means of safely stopping runaway vehicles. They consist of a long bed of loose, soft material, and sometimes an uphill slope.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, what does a lack of spray from other vehicles indicate?
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerB: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The tires have soaked up all the moisture.
questions.explanation: If the road appears to be wet but the wheels of other vehicles are no longer generating spray, ice has formed on the road. Drive with extra caution when operating on wet or icy roads.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.answerB: Black ice
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet instead of icy. Always be on the lookout for black ice if a road surface looks wet and temperatures are around the freezing mark.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: If you find yourself being tailgated by another driver, you should increase your following distance and avoid making quick moves. Increasing your speed may only result in the other driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed. Do not turn on your taillights or flash your brake lights at the other driver.

questions.question: Using a helper when backing up a large vehicle is:
questions.answerB: Discouraged.
questions.explanation: Backing a CMV is always dangerous due to limited visibility, so using a helper to monitor your blind spots is encouraged whenever possible.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerB: Parallel park.
questions.answerC: Drive straight into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: If stopped on the side of the road, how should you alert other motorists?
questions.answerB: Sound your horn.
questions.answerD: Keep the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important to turn on your four-way emergency flashers to warn other road users.

questions.question: If you’re unfamiliar with the area in which you must back up, you should:
questions.answerA: Get out of your vehicle and walk around the area to become more familiar with it.
questions.answerB: Not use both mirrors, as that can cause too much distraction.
questions.answerC: Wait for someone else to back up in the area so you see how they do it.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle. Especially if you are unfamiliar with the area, you should get out of your vehicle and familiarize yourself with your path of travel before beginning to back up.

questions.question: An example of required emergency equipment is:
questions.answerB: A loud horn.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: What should you do if the braking system cannot build up hydraulic pressure?
questions.answerB: Downshift.
questions.answerC: Hold the brake pedal down as far as it will go.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic braking system will not build up the pressure needed to slow or stop your vehicle, there are a few possible solutions. Try shifting into a lower gear, pumping the brakes, and/or using the emergency brake.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Can only be caused by physical distractions.
questions.answerB: Can only be caused by mental distractions.
questions.answerC: Can be caused by physical and/or mental distractions.
questions.answerD: Can only be caused by cell phone use.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts).

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerB: Usually has slowed perception.
questions.answerC: Is usually aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerD: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Driving while distracted may result in slowed perception, delayed decision-making, and improper actions. Watch for distracted drivers and avoid them, when possible.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: There may be extra weight in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything behind your vehicle. If you must drive in reverse, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best advice for driving in fog?
questions.answerA: Try not to drive in fog.
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous and should be avoided entirely if at all possible. If you must drive in fog, be sure to turn on your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: When planning to drive a bus that has been parked for a few days:
questions.answerA: The driver should assume the interior is in good working order.
questions.answerB: The driver should call the local police department.
questions.answerC: The driver should do a walkthrough inspection to ensure no damage has occurred since the last trip.
questions.answerD: The driver should ask the passengers to check the interior of the bus.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. Before driving a bus that has been unattended, you should check the interior to confirm that everything is in proper condition.

questions.question: When making a tight maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your mirrors, as they can be distracting.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors, but not too frequently.
questions.answerD: Rely only on your mirrors.
questions.explanation: Make a point of checking your mirrors often when making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: When driving a bus with passengers, you should:
questions.answerA: Not engage in conversation with the passengers.
questions.answerB: Fuel the bus with the passengers on board.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of distraction, bus drivers should not engage in conversation with passengers. Avoid fueling a bus while passengers are on board. Do not tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle, unless it would be unsafe for the passengers to exit the bus at the location where it has stalled.

questions.question: Move over laws require a driver approaching a stopped emergency vehicle to:
questions.answerA: Move into a lane that is not next to the stopped vehicle.
questions.answerB: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Move into the far portion of their lane.
questions.answerD: Increase their speed.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights is stopped on the side of a multilane road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: When using your mirrors, you should frequently look at your tires to:
questions.answerB: See if the tires are rolling properly.
questions.answerC: See if the tread is sufficient.
questions.answerD: Get a sense of the size of the tire in relation to other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Check your tires regularly when looking in your mirrors. This helps ensure that you will notice a tire fire, if one should happen. Tire fires may occur when a tire is under-inflated, if dual tires are touching, or if the tires are otherwise overheated.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts could be loose.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.answerB: Temperature.
questions.answerD: Traffic.
questions.explanation: Stopping distance is affected by a vehicle's speed. The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become.

questions.question: When checking tires, finding which of the following is not a cause for concern?
questions.answerB: Too little air pressure
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.answerD: Tread of at least 2/32 an inch on rear tires
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's tires, you should confirm that air pressure is neither too low nor too high; that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires; that there is at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth in grooves on other tires; and that radial and bias-ply tires are not used together.

questions.question: If a vehicle is accompanied by a vehicle inspection report:
questions.answerA: The driver should first inspect the vehicle, then compare their notes with the report.
questions.answerB: The driver should first look at the report when completing an inspection.
questions.answerC: The driver should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and should rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: As the first step of a vehicle inspection, a driver should review any inspection report left by the previous driver.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.answerB: Sunshine.
questions.answerD: Traffic.
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect your vehicle's stopping distance include driving speed, the vehicle's weight, and the slipperiness of the road surface.

questions.question: If you’re unfamiliar with the area in which you must back up, you should:
questions.answerA: Get out of your vehicle and walk around the area to become more familiar with it.
questions.answerB: Not use both side mirrors because it can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Wait for someone else to back up in the area so you can see how they do it.
questions.explanation: Before backing up, you should get out of your vehicle and look at your line of travel. Check your clearance to the sides and overhead.

questions.question: A curve's posted design speed is:
questions.answerB: Safe for all vehicles, including buses.
questions.answerC: The minimum speed at which the curve should be driven.
questions.answerD: Not always safe for buses.
questions.explanation: Even under ideal weather conditions, a bus being driven at the posted design speed for a curve could either roll over or slide off the road. For safety, you should reduce your speed before driving a bus around a curve.

questions.question: When checking the exhaust system, it should be:
questions.answerB: Leaking.
questions.answerD: Cracked.
questions.explanation: When checking the exhaust system, you should verify that no parts of the system are loose, broken, or missing.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way to reduce crashes when turning right?
questions.answerB: Keep the tail end close to the curb.
questions.answerC: Keep an eye on oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Allow open space on your right side.
questions.explanation: When making a right turn, avoid turning too wide to the left. If you must swing into another lane to complete the turn, you should keep the rear of your vehicle close to the curb. Leaving space to the right of your vehicle while turning right may indicate to other drivers that you are turning left, so they may attempt to pass you on your right.

questions.question: Tires of mismatched sizes:
questions.answerA: May be used on a tractor.
questions.answerB: May be used on a trailer.
questions.answerC: Should be used in adverse weather conditions.
questions.answerD: Should not be used on a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Having tires of mismatched sizes on a vehicle is a problem that should be fixed if discovered during a vehicle inspection.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a tire that is not in the front of a commercial motor vehicle.
questions.answerB: 2/32 of an inch
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in work zones?
questions.answerB: Careless behavior by construction workers
questions.answerD: Equipment placed in the roadway
questions.explanation: Speeding traffic is the main cause of death and injury in work zones. Drive with special caution when traveling near road workers.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with:
questions.answerB: A flag.
questions.answerD: GPS.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS).

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.answerC: Put the vehicle in a higher gear.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: If you are confronted with an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to stay in their way.
questions.explanation: The best thing to do when confronted with an aggressive driver is to get out of their way, if possible. Avoid making eye contact, which could further provoke the driver. Ignore any hand gestures made by the driver.

questions.question: When inspecting your tires, you do not want to find:
questions.answerA: Tire tread that is 4/32 of an inch deep.
questions.answerB: Valve stems without damage.
questions.explanation: There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on front tires and 2/32 of an inch on other tires. Valve stems should not be cut or cracked. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: Which of the following is not acceptable emergency equipment?
questions.answerB: Six fuses
questions.answerD: Four yellow squares
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will need to show emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and a properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to adequately check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The water compressor belt.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts, if the vehicle is equipped.

questions.question: If brakes overheat while going down a downhill grade, they may:
questions.answerB: Stop working.
questions.explanation: Overuse of the brakes may cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is known as "fade."

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, a bus driver should:
questions.answerA: Stop between 15 and 50 feet before the nearest track.
questions.answerB: Drive cautiously, but not stop unless a train is crossing.
questions.answerC: Speed up to ensure the momentum will get them over the tracks.
questions.answerD: Roll up all the windows.
questions.explanation: A bus driver should stop between 15 and 50 feet before any railroad crossing and check for trains before proceeding across the tracks. The driver may open the door to improve their ability to see or hear any approaching trains.

questions.question: At railroad crossings, bus drivers:
questions.answerB: Do not need to stop, but must reduce their speed to 25 mph below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Do not need to stop, but must open the door to listen for trains.
questions.answerD: Must stop and check for any approaching trains.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing while driving a bus, you must stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track to look and listen for any approaching trains. Only proceed once you are certain that there are no approaching trains. You do not need to stop at streetcar crossings; if a police officer or flagger is directing traffic; if there is a green traffic signal at the crossing; or at crossings marked "exempt" or "abandoned."

questions.question: When about to drive a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up to ensure the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait for air pressure to build in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the engine starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the compressor to build up pressure to at least 100 psi in both systems.

questions.question: If your tractor is equipped with ABS but your trailer is not, the ABS:
questions.answerB: Will still improve your steering control.
questions.answerD: Will allow others to see when you brake.
questions.explanation: In a tractor-trailer combination, if the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the ABS will still improve the driver's steering control. The driver should keep an eye on the trailer and let up on the brakes if the trailer begins to swing out.

questions.question: You should test the low pressure warning signal by:
questions.answerA: Turning on the engine and applying the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly pressing and releasing the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Removing wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but allow the wheels to keep rolling.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up and the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake until the vehicle starts to slow.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.answerB: Voice-activated brakes.
questions.answerD: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: The speed of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: When an S-cam turns inside a brake drum, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Presses the brake shoes against the brake linings.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake linings against the wheel axles.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.answerB: Are only required on trailers.
questions.answerD: Are optional.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.answerB: Liquid air
questions.explanation: Air brakes function through the use of compressed air.

questions.question: A ____ allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes.
questions.answerB: Trailer air supply control
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is depressed, air brakes work:
questions.answerB: After a short delay.
questions.answerD: Only if the green lever on the control panel is pushed down.
questions.explanation: After the brake pedal is pushed down in a vehicle with air brakes, it takes a half-second or more for air to flow through the lines and make the brakes work. This contrasts with hydraulic brakes used in cars and light and medium trucks, which instantly begin working when the pedal is pushed.

questions.question: Dollies equipped with ABS are required to have malfunction lamps located where?
questions.answerB: On the left side
questions.answerD: On the top
questions.explanation: A dolly equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is required to have a yellow malfunction lamp located on its left side.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pushed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal’s resting position and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop a vehicle
questions.answerD: How faded the brakes are
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work. On vehicles with hydraulic brakes, the brakes work instantly when the pedal is pressed.

questions.question: While driving downhill, you should brake until you reach a speed that is ____ below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: 10 mph
questions.answerD: 20 mph
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle equipped with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Lift the brake pedal up.
questions.answerC: Pull out the air brake knob.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, you should simply press the brake pedal down.

questions.question: Brakes can get out of adjustment:
questions.answerB: During the winter.
questions.answerC: If they are used at all.
questions.answerD: If brakes on one side are used more often than brakes on the other side.
questions.explanation: Brakes are particularly prone to getting out out adjustment if they are hot. Use proper braking techniques to avoid letting your brakes overheat.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.answerB: Dual air brake systems.
questions.answerD: Quadruple air brake systems.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: Once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi, the air compressor governor will:
questions.answerA: Stop the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerB: Release air from the tanks.
questions.answerC: Begin pumping air into the tanks.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level around 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake only needs to be used if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.answerC: The parking brake should not be used, as it can damage the tires.
questions.explanation: In general, you should always use the parking brake when parking your vehicle. However, you should not apply the parking brake if your brakes are very hot or if your brakes are wet and temperatures are below freezing.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Used while driving.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Used to stop the vehicle in normal driving.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied every time you park your vehicle.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal. If the warning signal goes off while a vehicle is being driven, the driver should bring the vehicle to a complete stop and have the system repaired.

questions.question: The air pressure in a dual air brake system should build from 85 to 100 psi within:
questions.answerB: 15 seconds.
questions.answerD: 45 seconds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: Shift into a lower gear, then use brakes to supplement the braking effect of the engine.
questions.answerC: The vehicle should be continually downshifted in the place of using the brakes.
questions.answerD: The vehicle should be driven on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the braking effect of the engine should be your primary method of controlling speed. Shift down to a lower gear before starting down the hill and save the brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: To stop in a vehicle that uses air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Engage the brake lever.
questions.answerD: Pull the brake pedal up.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle with air brakes, push the brake pedal down. The harder the pedal is pressed, the more air pressure is released.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually has a certain amount of water and oil in it. This can harm the system if allowed to accumulate. Air tanks have drain valves to aid in removing water and oil from the compressed air.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerB: Brakes being exposed to moisture.
questions.explanation: If brakes are overused, they can become too hot. This overheating causes them to fade, making them less effective at slowing the vehicle.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.answerD: Clean the air in the passenger compartment.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes. Manually operated drains should be used daily.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.answerB: Free of oil.
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: What helps prevent wheel lockup when braking?
questions.answerB: Air brakes
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheel lockup while brakes are being applied.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.answerB: Pushing a yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: Air brakes are:
questions.answerA: An effective tool for stopping large vehicles.
questions.answerB: Prohibited on large vehicles.
questions.answerD: A tool to improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: As long as the brakes are properly maintained, using air brakes is a safe and effective method of stopping large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual air brake system, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Let the air compressor build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in the primary and secondary systems before driving.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in both the primary and secondary systems. Watch the air pressure gauges to monitor the pressure levels.

questions.question: ABS brakes:
questions.answerB: Lock up your vehicle's wheels.
questions.answerC: Prevent your vehicle from accelerating when going uphill.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.answerB: Bluetooth.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.answerB: Voice-activated brakes.
questions.answerD: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.answerB: A parking brake system
questions.answerD: An axle brake system
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing a brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to the braking system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal more sensitive.
questions.answerD: Create a loud noise.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can release air from the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is ____ in a minute.
questions.answerB: 4 psi
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Air compressor governor
questions.answerD: Drum brake
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: The rods in S-cam brakes move the slack adjusters when air pressure is added to the brake chambers. This air pressure is added to the chambers when the driver:
questions.answerB: Uses the emergency brake.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.answerB: Outside air
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in an air brake system is releasing air:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned as this is a normal process.
questions.answerB: There is something wrong with the brakes.
questions.explanation: The safety relief valve in an air brake system releases air if necessary to prevent pressure in the system from becoming too high. If the valve starts releasing air, there is something wrong. Have a mechanic fix the problem.

questions.question: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Tightens the brake drum onto the axle.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake lining against the wheel.
questions.answerD: Releases air from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: It stops the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerB: It turns on the air compressor.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the storage tanks. It stops pumping if the pressure in the tanks becomes too high, and begins pumping if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: Front brake limiting valves were intended to:
questions.answerA: Prevent the front tires from skidding.
questions.answerB: Prevent the front tires from overheating.
questions.answerD: Remove uncertainty when applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles with air brakes have front brake limiting valves. These valves were intended to reduce the risk of front wheels skidding. However, research has shown that such devices are unnecessary, so they should be left in the "normal" position.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: What does ABS do?
questions.answerB: Prevent the air compressor from overheating
questions.answerC: Prevent the front brakes from being used on ice
questions.answerD: Prevent the brakes from being used if downshifting would be more effective
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheels from locking up during hard applications of the brakes, especially on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: When parked on a flat surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use wheel chocks to prevent your vehicle from moving.
questions.answerB: Not use wheel chocks.
questions.answerC: Use wheel chocks, but only if you have applied the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking on a level surface, you should use wheel chocks. If the vehicle is not equipped with spring brakes, this is essential to prevent the trailer from moving.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Loaded with most weight on the driver’s side of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed near the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Cargo weight should be evenly distributed within a trailer to reduce the risk of a rollover. Do not place too much weight on one side of a trailer.

questions.question: A trailer that is too high:
questions.answerB: Will couple securely.
questions.explanation: Before coupling together a tractor and a trailer, you should make sure the trailer is at the proper height. If the trailer is too low, the trailer nose may be damaged. If the trailer is too high, it may not be able to couple correctly.

questions.question: Trailers manufactured after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles is most prone to the “crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.answerB: A three-axle tractor
questions.answerD: A triple combination
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations are the most vulnerable to turning over as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: A lightly-loaded combination vehicle will stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have high traction.
questions.answerB: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have low traction.
questions.answerC: The brakes only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.answerD: The suspension springs only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction on a light trailer than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: What does an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) do?
questions.answerA: It allows a vehicle's wheels to lock up.
questions.answerB: It prevents a vehicle's wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: It makes turning a vehicle easier.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. If ABS detects impending lockup, it reduces braking pressure to a safe level.

questions.question: If color-coded, which color is used to identify service lines?
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.explanation: Air lines are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes when coupling glad hands. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.answerB: The utility line
questions.answerD: The parallel line
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line may also be referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.answerB: Deactivate the air brakes.
questions.answerD: Supply the trailer with air.
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerB: You are stopped.
questions.answerC: You take a turn too fast.
questions.explanation: Rollovers are caused by operators turning too fast. To avoid rolling over, drive slowly on entrance ramps, on exit ramps, and around corners. Avoid making quick lane changes when towing trailers.

questions.question: Combination vehicles:
questions.answerA: Often have taller trailers than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are usually lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Require more skill to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Driving combination vehicles requires more skill than driving single commercial vehicles. Combinations are generally longer, generally heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollover.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents a truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from driving too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: In a combination rig, it is best to make:
questions.answerB: Sharp turns.
questions.answerD: Slow, planned stops.
questions.explanation: When driving a combination vehicle, it is important to brake well in advance and look far ahead of your vehicle to avoid the need for sudden stops. Making habits of these actions will help you prevent your trailer from jackknifing.

questions.question: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should:
questions.answerB: Back toward the driver's side.
questions.answerC: Swerve back and forth while backing.
questions.answerD: Always turn to your right.
questions.explanation: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should back on a curved path toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This will permit you the best possible visibility while backing.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerD: To test the lights on the trailer.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: If a trailer is too high:
questions.answerA: It will not make a difference when coupling.
questions.answerB: It may not couple correctly.
questions.answerD: Coupling will be easier.
questions.explanation: Before coupling together a tractor and a trailer, you should make sure the trailer is at the proper height. If the trailer is too low, the trailer nose may be damaged. If the trailer is too high, it may not be able to couple correctly.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to close.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer to detach from the combination.
questions.answerD: The suspension springs to extend.
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the trailer's braking system should the trailer break away or develop a leak. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the tractor protection valve to open and the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: If you press the tractor air supply control and your trailer's spring brakes do not release, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate the Anti-Lock Braking System.
questions.answerC: Turn the engine off and on again.
questions.explanation: It is important that all of a vehicle's equipment is in proper working condition before beginning a trip. If a trailer's spring brakes do not release when you push in the tractor air supply control, you should make sure the air line connections are properly attached and sealed.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.answerB: The utility line
questions.answerD: The parallel line
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line may also be referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: Keeping cargo low can:
questions.answerB: Help you drive faster.
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from going too fast
questions.answerD: A valve that prevents the trailer from accidentally being released
questions.explanation: In a combination vehicle with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system in the event of the trailer breaking away or developing a leak.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.answerB: Over railroad crossings.
questions.answerD: At the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.answerB: Supply line.
questions.answerD: Steering wheel.
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: When lightly loaded, combination vehicles:
questions.answerB: Have reduced braking capabilities.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with most of the weight in the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When a combination vehicle is lightly loaded, it may have poor traction. It is very easy for wheels to lock up on lightly-loaded vehicles when they are being stopped.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: In a sudden turn, the ____ trailer is the most likely to turn over.
questions.answerB: Last
questions.answerD: First
questions.explanation: When making a turn, be sure to steer gently and smoothly. Making a quick turn while pulling trailers is dangerous and can increase the risk of the last trailer rolling over.

questions.question: To control surge when stopping, you should not:
questions.answerA: Keep a steady pressure on the brakes.
questions.answerB: Brake well in advance of a stop.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a surge in a tank vehicle, slow or stop while keeping a steady pressure on the brakes and do not release the brakes too early. Brake well in advance of a stop and increase your following distance.

questions.question: When coupling, after you've connected the air lines to the trailer, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate the emergency brake.
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles is most prone to the “crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.answerB: A three-axle tractor
questions.answerD: A triple combination
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations are the most vulnerable to turning over as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: Compared to other commercial motor vehicles, combination vehicles need more space on the road because they are longer and they:
questions.answerA: Need more space to turn and stop.
questions.answerB: Drive more slowly.
questions.answerD: Swerve more often.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerB: A trailer to straighten out.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should not be used while you are driving because:
questions.answerA: It will disconnect from the vehicle.
questions.answerB: You will stop the vehicle too quickly.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: When the wheels of a trailer lock up:
questions.answerB: The trailer tends to swing around.
questions.answerC: The cab will swing, but the trailer will stay straight.
questions.answerD: They will likely go flat.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: To prevent a trailer from rolling over, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up when nearing a corner.
questions.answerB: Make sudden steering moves.
questions.answerC: Take on-ramps faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerD: Drive slowly around corners.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover when driving a combination vehicle, you should keep the weight of the cargo as low to the ground as possible and drive slowly around turns.

questions.question: Having anti-lock brakes on only one axle:
questions.answerA: Will not make a difference in braking.
questions.answerB: Will provide increased control in braking.
questions.answerC: Will likely cause the air brakes to malfunction.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle has anti-lock brakes on just one axle, the driver will still have more control during braking than they would without any anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: If the trailer begins to skid, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Quickly turn the steering wheel one way, then the other.
questions.answerD: Brake.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to skid, you should release the brakes to help regain traction. Once the wheels grip the road again, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the path of the tractor.

questions.question: Trailers manufactured after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
